Description: Egyptian mould-made oil-lamp. Flat pear-shaped base with elongated body and raised moulded or stamped decoration on rim. Decoration of curved lines on concave discus. The broad shallow channel from edge of discus to nozzle is slightly blackened through use. Simple lug at back. Pale red-brown Nile silt with white and mica inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late Roman parallels from Egypt in the British Museum (EA 1912,1109.656; Bailey 2207). End 6th to beginning of the 7th century BC parallels from Kom el- Dikka, Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 350, Fig 23). Parallels in the British Museum dated 6th to 7th century AD (Bailey 1988, Q2203-7). Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KF.03) (Phase 3)
